turns.speaker: CAMPBELL
turns.text: I think we'd better discuss this in my office, Mr. Mitchell.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Nothing to discuss. Tomorrow the sun will shine even brighter. Be grateful for small mercies.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm getting positively haggard. In a couple of years people will be describing me as well preserved.

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: I see out friend Larry Mitchell is with us again.

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: So much less refined than frizzling them in the chair.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Oh, shut up!  You haven't even got your spats on.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: I don't think you locked your door.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: See how easy it is? Perhaps Miss Mayfield left her door unlocked. Or if she didn't, there's a passkey on every floor in the linen room. The head porter has a passkey. The bell captain has a passkey. The hotel's full of passkeys.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Passkey?

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: Or--since one is a well-known and respected guest--one could go to the desk in the lobby and say "Miss Mayfield seems to have lost her room key--have you another"?  They always have another.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Don't be a fool. I loved him. He wasn't worth it, but I loved him.

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: And now that he's safe from all other women, you can go on loving him.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You nasty, sardonic--

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: Sardonic, if you will my dear. Bust nasty. You lied about the gun.

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: I'm a very observant man. You had something in your bag this afternoon, Something that causes you to hold it in a particular way. Something that made a particular sound when you put it down on the bar. You went out with Mitchell. None of us ever saw him again.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That's not enough.

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: I saw your face this evening when the detective showed you the gun. You lied. It was obvious.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: He saw my face too.

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: So he did--but he hasn't told you what he saw. I have.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: They'll arrest that girl. Everything points to her.

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: Convenient, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: One of these days, you're going to wake up in the middle of the night and find that you've cut your throat.

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: How clumsy. I'd never forgive myself. Good night my dear.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You could have got in that room, just as you got in here. How do I know you didn't kill Larry?

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: With what motive?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Nastiness. You're nasty with words. Why wouldn't you be nasty with deeds once in a while? You hated him--and I know why.

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: He was very easy to hate. If you'll look in your mirror, when you are in a better temper- you'll know why.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Mr. Clarendon, have you ever seen this before?

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: I'm sorry, Inspector, I don't know much about..

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Recently, then.

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: No, Not recently. I'm sure of that.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I needn't keep you any longer, Mr. Clarendon.

turns.speaker: CLARENDON
turns.text: Thank you. It is rather late... and I'm not young anymore. Good night.

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: The Harbor police have just picked up a dead man out of the water.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Floater?

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: Not a floater.  Only just dead.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: You're the waterfront specialist. Find out about it.  I've got a murder to investigate.

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: You have two murders to investigate. This man's head was beaten in. And there's nothing in his pockets.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Drunk-rolling job.  They hit him too hard.

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: I've been on the waterfront detail for twelve years.  This man hadn't been dead an hour.  He wasn't killed last night.  He was killed today. In broad daylight.  That's no drunk- rolling job.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Let me know when you've identified him

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: And don't get too logical, Driscoll. In police business it doesn't work. I wish it did.  But it doesn't

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: I'm an Irishman, sir.  An Irishman is always logical.

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: Got a moment, Inspector?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I've got a year.  Or a second. I'm not sure which.

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: You told me when we'd identified this fellow--

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: We've done that.  He's a San Francisco private eye.  Name Martin J. Goble, G-O-B-L-E.  Had initials in his hat and for once he lived where he bought it.  Goble and Greer is the firm name.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Swimming with his hat on?  That's original.

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: If you'd seen the blood on his head--and some body had to carry him out to sea--

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I understand.  Pity to mess up a nice clean boat.

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: I got through to Greer, his partner in the detective business.  Greer won't give out.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I'd suggest a telegram.  Something like this: Chief of Police, San Francisco.  A licensed private detective named named Martin J. Goble, address so-and-so, has been found murdered within our jurisdiction.  His partner, name something-something Greer, refuses to give us any information. Correction.  Refuses information necessary to our investigation. Can you assist?  Signed Detective Sergeant Driscoll, Vancouver, British Columbia, Police.

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: Send that?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Would you?

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: If you're asking my opinion, no. I'd read it to Greer over the phone. Ask him if he had any objections.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Catch me at the Vancouver Royal if it's important.

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: How important would it have to be? It's only murder, Inspector.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: The Super's just given me the sweetest dressing down I've ever had.  I'm still reeling from it. And believe me, I had it coming. I apologize.  What you think is important--I think is important.

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: Thanks, Inspector.  What are your orders about this wire to San Francisco?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Men like you don't need orders.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: What's the face for, Driscoll?

turns.speaker: DRISCOLL
turns.text: Magruder's conked out.  Adrenaline injections, oxygen tent.  He may come out of it and he may not.  As a source of quick information, we can't forget him.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: We don't need him.

turns.speaker: GOBLE
turns.text: I'm looking for Mr. Brandon.

turns.speaker: MAGRUDER
turns.text: The joint's not open, Mac.  Who's Brandon?

turns.speaker: GOBLE
turns.text: I have an appointment with him, right here, right now.

turns.speaker: MAGRUDER
turns.text: Go live in a tent.

turns.speaker: GOBLE
turns.text: It'll be a tough dollar when guys like you learn the alphabet.

turns.speaker: MAGRUDER
turns.text: Talk English.  How do I know you're you?

turns.speaker: MAGRUDER
turns.text: Mr. Brandon couldn't be here.  He might have left something for you. What would it look like?

turns.speaker: GOBLE
turns.text: One of those nice long manila envelopes--sealed.  Not too fat- not too thin.

turns.speaker: MAGRUDER
turns.text: What do I get for it?

turns.speaker: GOBLE
turns.text: You get it's brother.

turns.speaker: MAGRUDER
turns.text: Sounds like a fair swap.  Let's take a look.

turns.speaker: MAGRUDER
turns.text: I need a receipt.  Sign your name across the flap.

turns.speaker: GOBLE
turns.text: Open it and count it.

turns.speaker: MAGRUDER
turns.text: When you sign for it, you count it.  It's your dough.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: You in charge here?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: So it seems Sergeant.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I hate to pull rank on you Sergeant, but once in a while...for moral purposes...you might address me as "Inspector". In moments of extreme desperation, you might even call me "sir".

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I knew him. He was easy to dislike, poor chap.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: They tell me he'll be a great loss to the liquor trade. This Mayfield girl...

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: ... I supposed you knew her, too, Inspector.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I've met her.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: It's her room. She only got to the Hotel this afternoon,. With him.  I guess he took too much for granted. Here's the gun.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Pearl-handled .25 Automatic, uh?  No, it's a Belgian gun... 6.6 mm.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Correct, Inspector. A woman's gun. U.S. 125 caliber ammunition in it. It was on a table in there.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: This make of gun throws a shell backwards, high, and to the right. The chaise is only about four feet from the wall.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: So the shell ought to have gone over?

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Unless the gun was slanted up.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: So the wound and the shell give you the same answer.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Right. A clean deduction from observed facts. They've got to be simple once in a while, Inspector.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I've always looked forward to it. All right, let's get him out of here and tidy up.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: She didn't seem the type to lam out--even if she got the chance. That stuff was all gone through last night.  Anything special you're looking for, Inspector?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I'll know when I find it.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: I guess I'm just ballast around here.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: "G.G. Market one-eight-four-two."

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Gigi, huh?  Sounds French--one of those fancy ladies.  Must have been very fancy, if he scratched her phone number in gold.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Market... It seems to me that's a San Francisco exchange.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: That's pretty risky business, Inspector.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Somebody did it twice last night-- in the dark.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Not too hard, is it?

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Maybe we've been pretty dumb--

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: There wasn't any motive...let's try out the act.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Was that about the right angle?

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Where's the shell?

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Should be over there.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: You've got a dead man on your hands. You killed jim--even if it wasn't murder.  What are you going to do about it?

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: If I've got any sense I'm going to call headquarters.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: They'll probably believe you.  But they'll want to know what you were fighting about.  Why Mitchell had a gun.  You'll tell them a simple story.  They'll pretend it sounds all right to them.  Now you're headquarters.  How does it sound to you?

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Before I took the story and closed the case, I'd want to know a lot more about these people.  I'd want to know just about everything about them.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Exactly.  Now I'm the killer.  And there's something I don't want you to know.  Something that would destroy my comfortable life, rob me of my friends, my position.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Such as?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Assume there is something to hid. I go to a lot of trouble.  What do I do?  What would you do?

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Do I know who lives down there?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: You can find out.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Do I know that she's out of the room?  Likely to be out of it for some time?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: You can find out the first part. The second part you have to take a chance on.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Pretty big chance, huh?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: You've got a dead man on your hands. Like this.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: This is the shell.  What about the gun?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Well.  What about it?

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: I've handled it.  Mitchell's handed it.  If I wipe it off, no suicide. If I take it out and lose it, no suicide.  If I leave it here....no suicide.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: I've got to find a way to handle it, openly.  Like Brandon.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: How did he know he'd get the chance? He couldn't have arranged it.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: He could have tried.  If he was up there in the dark, listening, he'd know when she came home, know when she found Mitchell dead, know what she did about it.  If she telephoned, he'd probably hear that.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: And she did give him the chance, the way it worked out.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: If she didn't--if luck was against him--he wipes the gun off, reaches the wall up there--drops it on the chaise.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: No suicide.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Did we ever really think it was suicide?

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: You win, Inspector.  You win all along the line.  Why didn't we think of Brandon before--or did we-- some of us.  Yeah.  Of course you did.  When a suspect thinks he's safe, you go on letting him think he's safe. Wait for a mistake.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: And a motive--which we haven't got.  So this could all be a dream.

turns.speaker: GORE
turns.text: Greer and Goble in the Call Building, San Francisco.  Just like you thought...Two murders in two days.  Different places, different methods, different people. Nothing connects them, but a telephone number.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: A think wire---but very, very strong.  Let's get out of here.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Oh, the Coldstream Guards.  Don't you take your hat off in elevators?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I never wear a hat.  Oh, so I am. I forgot.  I guess I'm terribly sorry again, Mrs. West.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: May you what?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Oh nothing.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Are you always this witty?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Scotch and plain water, I think.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Warm water, no doubt.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I never saw it before.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Positive?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What about me?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Not quiet yet.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: You knew Mitchell pretty well, didn't you, Mrs. West?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I was in love with him... which shows you the quality of my brains.  Why don't you ask her about the gun?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I shall. From your knowledge of Mitchell, would you say he would be likely to commit suicide?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Anybody could commit suicide, if he felt low enough. I've felt it myself.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Then why not give Miss Mayfield the benefit of the doubt?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'd be delighted to... anytime you can show me the doubt. I'll wrap it up in tissue paper and put a Christmas seals on it for her.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Thank you very much, Mrs. West.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Remember that time, didn't I? Good morning Mrs. West.  Does your visit here mean you've changed your mind?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How did you know?  Clarendon.  You cops never tell anybody anything, do you.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Other people always know so much more than we know--so much more than they're willing to tell us.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It was Clarendon.  He knew I had the gun in my bag.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You couldn't possible have traced it this soon--not possibly.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Of course not.  Thanks for telling me.  I haven't seen Mr. Clarendon.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I am a fool.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: That depends upon your motive. You were in love with Mitchell, weren't you?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Yes--and he's already becoming vague to me.  Funny!  Last night I was furiously jealous.  Jealous of what?  I out that gun in my bag deliberately.  Who was I going to kill with it?  A girl I didn't even know?  A man I knew to be a thief and a forger?  A half-man? A gigolo?  It's already ludicrous. Love!  What a comedy!

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: You didn't play it for laughs last night.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Did you ever have a serious operation?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Mortar shells are not funny, either.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: At first, it doesn't hurt at all. That's shock.  Then it hurts terribly--you wouldn't believe such pain could exist--and six months later you can't remember what pain felt like.  It hasn't taken six months this time.  It hasn't even taken twenty- four hours.  Is that a beastly thing to say?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Not if it clears the air.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It does.  May I go now?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I'll investigate Mr. Clarendon's financial position--

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Perhaps a rich widow would have solved all his problems.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Now, you're being beastly.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Sure.  You didn't come here in person just to tell me about the gun.  You wanted me to be looking across the desk at you while you talked about Mitchell.  If I believe you, it would be psychologically impossible for you to have killed him last night.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: And if you didn't believe me?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: You would still have planted information that Clarendon knew about the gun--and not as an accusation, but in the process of defending yourself by making a confession.  Very neat.  Good morning, Mrs. West.

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: Yes, I think so.  Here are two glazed manila envelopes.  One is the bag type.  The other one had the money in it.  Don't ask me how I know.  I know.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I'm interested in who handled it.

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: Four different people, Inspector. Three men and a women.  I've made slides for two.  They handled both envelopes.

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: No doubt about that one.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: How about Magruder?

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: He checks too.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: That leaves two strangers.

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: So far.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Try Betty Mayfield.  The Mitchell case.

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: Mayfield?  She fit into this?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: She might.

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: You'll have to take my word for it.  We don't make slides until we have perfect prints for comparison.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I'll take your word.

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: This gun permit was issued to Clark Brandon?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: The card says so, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: Brandon handled the money envelope.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: Killaine, this is Mr. Mitchell, Senior.  Young Mitchell's father. He just flew in from Toronto.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: How do you do, sir.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: I've explained the situation to Mr. Mitchell up to a point.  Now about this Mayfield girl?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: She's a suspect, naturally.  But not the only one.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: She's the only one who had a dead man in her room.  The only one who won't give an account of herself. The only one who tried to run away. And the only one, so far, I've been told, who went to such lengths to disguise her identity that she even removed the labels from her clothes.  What more do you want?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: I hear she's a very pretty girl.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Which forces me to arrest her against my better judgment.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: Aye.  You have a point there.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Am I to interpret that as an order to arrest Miss Mayfield?

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: When I give an order, you'll not need it interpreted.  You have an hour to make your mind up.  Well, are ye satisfied, Mr. Mitchell?

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: Are you a policeman or a soft-headed nincompoop?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: A little of both, sir, and perhaps not quiet enough of either.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: It won't look pretty good on your record, Killaine.  Where's the girl now?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I don't know, sir.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: Well, find out.  Who's covering her?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Nobody's covering her, I detached the officer assigned to that duty.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: This girl is a murderess, Killaine.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I disagree, sir.  As Inspector in charge of the case I have the right to form that opinion, the right to act on it.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: Ye have, have ye?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: We lifted seven fairly good prints from Miss Mayfield's toilet articles.  Washington ought to teletype us within a few hours.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: And in the meantime this girl goes where she pleases, does what she pleases?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: "Superintendent J. Mckechnie, Vancouver Police Department. Vancouver B.c. Replaying To Your E.P. teletype classification No. 2684 incomplete.  We advise identification possible.  Elizabeth Kinsolving, arrested Greenwater, North Carolina, January 8, 1948, on a charge of murder.  Signed, FBI., Washington, D.C. H. Cleary, Inspector in charge."  Have ye any comment, Killaine?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Identification on possible, Sir. Not conclusive.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: "Superintendent J. McKechnie, Vancouver Police Department. Replying your inquiry Elizabeth Kinsolving.  Subject was indicted, first degree murder her husband, Lee Kinsolving, January this year. Guilty verdict set aside by presiding judge.  Prisoner discharged, Whereabouts now unknown. Fingerprint classification"--  And exact correspondence, Killaine.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: "Physical description: Age 26, Height 5  1 3/4 inches: Weight, 188 pounds: Light brown hair: Deep blue eyes: Small, perfectly formed features: Ears and earlobes small: Slender build: Wears size 4 AA shoe: Quiet refined manner: New York accent: No charges pending. No prior criminal record.  Mayfield, Mother's name.  Air-mailing you photographs today.  Signed Hubert Tollison, Chief of Police, Greenwater, North Carolina."  She bleached her hair, or course.  Would your sensibilities be offended, if I sent out a general alarm to pick up this girl?

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I think you'd be entirely justified, sir.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: But you still think she's innocent.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: I believe you won decorations during the war.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Two.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: There are people in this world who don't think a police badge is a badge of honor.  I'm not one of them.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Nor I. This is why I gave it to you.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: You're a young man.  You're romantic.  You think a pretty face and a clean conscience go together. You think a soft voice means a soft heart.  You'll grow out of that.

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: Not too far, I hope.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: This badge is not an old newspaper you can cast down on the desk.  It is not a thing you can give up as of no value.  It may be taken from you--and you may die defending it. But you'll not use it to make cheap dramatic gesures with.  It's a naked steel of the sword of Justice.  Put it back in your pocket and hold tight to it--and someday you might grow into a worthiness ye lack now.

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: Get out of here!

turns.speaker: KILLAINE
turns.text: What are my orders, sir?

turns.speaker: MCKECHNIE
turns.text: You think I'm wrong about this bit of a girl.  Go out and prove it against me!

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm afraid you're not very glad to see me, Margo.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: With your charm? How could I help it? Have a nice trip?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: So-so.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Who's the girl?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Her name's Mayfield. Betty Mayfield.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Nice.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: She's just a girl I met on the train. You don't mind do you?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Why should I mind?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: You shouldn't. You washed me up very thoroughly.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: As thoroughly as I could. It wasn't easy. But you are helping me.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Margo, darling. You washed me up. Remember? We're just friends. You wanted it that way.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She's very beautiful. She's much younger than I am. And she's rich, I hope.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Rich? I haven't the faintest idea. Why?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You ought to know why.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I don't. My hunch is she's just torn up an unhappy marriage. I was able to do her a small favor.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Splendid. Now she can return the compliment.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I hoped to get enough to cover them before they cleared. I wasn't lucky.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You know what would happen to you if I turned these over to the police?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I have a rough idea.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You'd go to jail. For a long term.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Correct. I couldn't even afford to pay a lawyer to defend me.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: What'll we do about it, Margo?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She is much younger than I am. That's something I'm going to have to get used to. Isn't it, Larry? They'll all be much younger than I am. Here.  Tear them up.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I've always been a heel. I guess I always will be.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You don't have to make a pose of it.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: It's the only pose I have left. I'm sunk. Broke. I don't even have my hotel bill.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I seem to recognize this routine. First the kiss then the touch.  Oh, what's the use. You're you.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I seem to remember that you like to help yourself.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That's not very kind.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Kind or not kind. What's the difference? It always ends up the same way.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What does it look like?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: How long have you had it?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Years, why?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: It's against the law to cross the border with a gun. The Canadian police might like to know about this.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You already have the checks, darling.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I didn't mean it that way  I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Oh, forget it. Clark Brandon's throwing a party up in his penthouse this evening. Take me?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How about your new friend?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I told you she's just..

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: A girl you meet on the train. Excuse my bringing it up again.  Be back in an hour. Right?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: In an hour, Larry.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm sorry. I forgot about calling for you.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It's quite unimportant, Mr. Mitchell. After all, you got what you wanted.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Be nasty.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I have no intension of being nasty, Mr. Mitchell.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: In that case, there's someone here I'd like to introduce to you. Over there.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She is beautiful. And young.  No thank you.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: I say YES!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You're very attractive, my dear. And you look very unsophisticated.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Unsophisticated?  If I knew about this babe...

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Mr. Penfield.  I am sorry to have kept you.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: It's kind of you to see me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Tom, Daddy would like to see you in the garden.  And will you ask Betty to bring us some coffee. And remember to say 'please'.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: He's a little unhappy.  I hope he wasn't a nuisance?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: He was delightful.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: My first husband worked for the BBC.  I doubt if anyone there remembers him now, just another long dead diligent administrator. He would have been useful in the fight to preserve the BBC's independence during the Suez crisis - one of the few things he was passionate about.  I became involved too.  I started work on a book that would have been published on the tenth anniversary of Suez. Then he died, and I loots the will to write it.  By the time I was over his death, other books had been published, and it wasn't worth going on.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: What a shame.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: It wasn't much more than a pot boiler.Suez was very important for our generation.  I didn't want it to be forgotten.  And that's why I'd like to be able to help you. But really Mr. Penfield, I looked through my notes before you came, they're all very much out of date, there's been so much published since.  I don't think I'm your man.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Well, I am a great admirer of your work.  I read your books on Chartism when I was still at school.  I'm a journalist, not a historian.  There are questions of method, and approach.  I wondered--

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I see.  Are you a socialist, Mr. Penfield?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Good.  Suez was a minefield for both parties.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: My husband apologises for not joining us.  It's not too cold for you, Mr. Penfield?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: It's fine, thank you.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Since you are a friend of my daughter's, I think I'm entitled to call you James, don't you think?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Please do.  I was beginning to wonder who this Mr. Penfield was.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: And I'd like you to call me Ann.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: To Ann.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: To James.  I remember what it was I was going to say.  We were talking about forgetfulness.  The Czech writer Kundera has one of his characters say that the struggle of man against tyranny is the struggle of memory against forgetting.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: History books are first onto the bonfires.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: If we leave the remembering to historians then the struggle is already lost.  Everyone must have a memory, everyone needs to be a historian.  In this country, for example, we're in danger of losing hard-won freedoms by dozing off in a perpetual present.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Here I am lecturing you.  Have some pâté.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: So I can go ahead and be a historian without feeling like a poseur.I shall be fulfilling a citizen's duty.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: If you like.  But don't be too modest, James.  The citizen's duty is to remember, not necessarily to write books.  You are highly qualified.  You're a responsible journalist doing what sounds to me like a very demanding job.  Every day you take decisions that depend on your sense of history.  A genuine tyranny would have to get rid of people like you.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You're kind to be so encouraging.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I think you'll do very well.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I do worry about Susan.  Have you known her long?  She hasn't mentioned you.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Actually, we've only just met. But we're quiet good friends.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: It's a pity she couldn't make it up here today.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: She'll be here next weekend.  Why don't you come too, James?  I'll                       * show you the marshes properly.  If you're lucky you might even see the first of the geese arriving from Siberia.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Well, I'd hate to be a nuisance.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Don't be silly.  I'll look out some more Suez material for you. You'll be very welcome.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: We'll see you next week, and if--

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: The references are to Hansard or to newspapers.  I haven't got the actual speeches now.  You'll have to chase them up.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I will, thanks.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: These are transcripts of various radio broadcasts, including Gaitskill's, the one they tried to stop.  You ought to have that ...

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Hello.  Anyone for a walk?  Tom isn't, I can tell you.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Well, we were just...

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Shall we go?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Then I began to listen to what the well-off were saying about the poor now  the war had just ended, and the language was much the same as it had been before the first Reform Act.  A small minority thought that England was really theirs, they had made it, they owned it.  The rest, the wage earners, were foreigners, outsiders intent on wrecking it all.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Didn't Evelyn Waugh say that the country under Atlee seemed to be under enemy occupation?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Did he?  I left school and worked for the Labour Party.  My older brother, George, had just been killed in Greece, and he'd been an active member.  I hero-worshipped him.  He was 25 years old ...  It was an exciting time for us, those first couple of years after the war.  We thought the country was about to become a true democracy.  I can understand why people of your generation want to write about that time.  They feel betrayed.  They want to know what went wrong.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: What went wrong?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, many things.  Inertia ... Stalin and the Cold War... a failure of nerve.  We took the seediest, most inefficient fifth of the economy into State care, paid out millions for it, put the same old duffers in charge.  A new broom with very old bristles.  When the Tories were returned, I went and sat in the BM and wrote my little book on Chartism.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: CARMEN
turns.text: Sit on that log, dear.

turns.speaker: CARMEN
turns.text: Now first of all, tell us your name.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Penfield.  James Penfield.

turns.speaker: CARMEN
turns.text: This is Jill, Carol, Betty, Mandy, Louise, Pete over there, and I'm Carmen.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: But I'm not an interviewer or a correspondent.

turns.speaker: CARMEN
turns.text: That doesn't matter.  As long as we can get our message through to someone there.  Jill, where are those handouts?

turns.speaker: CARMEN
turns.text: Give them here.  This tells you how the Women's Peace Camp came to be set up.  All local women at first, then we had support from women and men all over the country.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Very good.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Terrific.

turns.speaker: CARMEN
turns.text: But what we need is national coverage.  It's difficult with this Falklands madness going on. Do you think you might be able to do something when you get back?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I'll suggest it.  Remember though, we're news, not features.  It might help if you could get yourselves attacked by the police.  Anyway, I'll be back with this soon. Thanks.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Charles!  I didn't know you were back.  Have a good holiday?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Not too bad, thanks.  How have you been?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Working hard on that book I was telling you about.  Coming to the meeting?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: I'm not sure I can face it.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Keep me company.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: How's Mary?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: She's fine.  Well, actually we've broken up.  It's all over.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: No.  That's terrible, Charles. What happened?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Look, I'd rather you didn't ask me questions.  I can't talk about it.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Aha.  James giving some woman the old heave-ho.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Exactly that.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: It's terribly good.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Don't tell me you've actually read it, Jeremy.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Committed to memory.  Forever.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Attributed?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Why, is there a new Foreign Secretary?  Who was the old one anyway?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: It needn't concern you, Edward. James has got some news.  He needs a poet's advice.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Congratulations.  Who with?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: A glamorous young lady way above his station...

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: I know, I know!  Gentlemen, let me introduce you to one of our most talented contributors to The Cold War.  James Penfield.  He wrote the opening chapter, on 'The Berlin Airlift'.  One of the best chapters in the book.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: I won't introduce you all by name. Basically James, this is our UK sales team.  What was I saying? Yes, these graduate trainees...

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: Would you like a dessert...I'm having one.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: No thanks.  I'd like to break away--

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: I'll have some of that.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: ...break away completely from--

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: And some of that.  Sorry.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: ...from all the moralising and talk of national humiliation that is now the standard line on Suez...

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: Yes...You're not a socialist then?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: No.  I'd want to--

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I'd want to set out events as they happened.  The way I see it is this: the British Empire was an ideal.  It may have become totally obsolete by the middle of this century, but it wasn't totally dishonourable to try and defend its remains and try and salvage some self-respect, which is what I think the Conservatives were trying to do.  Then there's the essential--

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: Are you going to have coffee?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Yes, please.

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: And you'll join me in a sambucca?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: Personally James, I'm very excited by this new arrangement we have. It gives us direct access to literally hundreds of American collages.  Twentieth century history is a growth area over there, don't ask me why.  Your readership will be first and second year American collage students...

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Freshman and sophomores...

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: You know the lingo.  Jolly good. So your language will have to be simple, not stupid, mind, but simple, very, very simple, and always remember it's an American readership.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Like I was saying, the American angle in Suez is very important. I wouldn't want to say they let us down.  I think that's wrong.  A good ally is one who doesn't back you up in your mistakes, who tells you when to pull back.  And the Americans were good allies.  Simple as that.

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: James... I can't begin to tell you how pleased we all are.  Congratulations, and I really mean it.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: GOLD
turns.text: It's everything we wanted.  A very good read.  A terrific piece of work.  So, here's to you and Suez.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: And to history.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: So it's all worked out perfectly...

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: That's her.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Was that your chapter, then?  It was very good.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Thank you.  We met last week, at the Wajda film.  You won't remember. We didn't actually speak.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yes, that's right.  I'm being terribly rude.  Bob?  Oh, Bob. This is Bob Tuckett.  Bon was at Oxford too.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Can I give you a lift?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: No, it's all right.  I can get a cab.  Night night.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: What did you think of that Wadja film?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I quite liked it.  I wasn't as enthusiastic as everyone else.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I thought it was tremendous.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I think it went on rather too long.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I couldn't bear for it to end.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: And I didn't like that man.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Oh, but he was terrific.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: And the shape of it all.  It was sort of...shapeless.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Really?  I thought those long flashbacks were extremely good.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You don't like flashbacks because your mother's a historian.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Good theory.  But I like my mother. I have no aversions to what she does.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Too bad.  What did your father do?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: My real father?  Well, he was a flashback.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Everyone describes the same process. At first it is exciting.  You're at the centre of the world.  As soon as anything happens, you're the first to know about it.  And there are deadlines a dozen times a day, even more, and that's intimidating and exciting.  Then you get the hang of it and the excitement wears off.  Your a clerk in a rather dowdy Office.  There's none of the glamour of television, or the penetration of serious journalism.  You're a processor of semi-official news.  Some people leave at this stage.  Then, if you hang on, and especially if you're promoted, you discover a new kind of pleasure.  You're pleased by the ease with which you can write summaries and bulletins from news agency printouts, by the way you ca judge length.  Ending a broadcast on the dot, having everything run smoothly, selecting a running order that makes sense, knowing instinctively what you can and cannot do.  Professionalism.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: And you're at this third stage

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: No, there's a fourth.  Numbness. You do everything right, but you feel nothing either way.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I think you're exaggerating.  And if you aren't, you should jolly well change your job.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Oh yes?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yes.  You're much too old to making a drama out of alienation, or whatever you call it.  You've got to take responsibility for your own happiness.  That's what I think anyway.
